A classmate of ours, who only recently came to these Pilgrim shores
from Greece, happened upon the
word "palfrey" in the course of his
French assignment. Not being certain of the exact connotation of the
term, he asked a sophomore friend
who, after perusing the context
thoroughly, outlined the meaning
in great detail. In order to make
sure that his memory would not fail
him, the interrogater copied the explanation in black and white.
Came the next day and French
class. When the instructor challengingly inquired, "Qu' est-ce que
veut dire un palefroi ?" our hero
triumphantly took up the gauntlet
and cried out, "A palfrey—why, a
palfrey is the same thing as a conference!"

Miss Frances Carpenter, of New
York, will be the sponsor for the
Musical Club Home Concert next
Friday night when the oldest campus activity celebrates its fiftieth
anniversary. Albert R. Hunt, business manager of the Club, will escort Miss Carpenter.
The sponsor is the daughter of
Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Carpenter, formerly of the Green Spring
Valley, and is quite well-known locally. She is a graduate of Penn
Hall School for Girls in Chambersburg,

KELLY AND CARNEY
EJECTED BY VOITH
Victory Enables Hopkins
Five To Finish In
Second Place
In a thrilling closing session in
which they overcame a first-period
14-9 lead, the Hopkins cagers defeated Loyola College Saturday
night, 33-28. This was the second
meeting of the two teams and the
Jays again proved their superiority
by repeating an early-season victory.
The triumph gives Hopkins a tie
for runner-up honors in the Maryland League. If Western Maryland
should defeat Mt. St. Mary's this
week, Hopkins will take second honors undisputed.
Loyola Begins Fast

The contest between the Jays and
Greyhounds packed all the thrills
that basketball spectators could ask
for. Loyola ran wild in the first
fifteen minutes of play to assume a
12-1 advantage, but Hopkins pulled
itself together and closed up the
count to 14-9 in favor of the Evergreen cagers at half time.
Only a few minutes after the
second half started, Don Kelly,
Hopkins guard, and Tom Carney,
Loyola, were evicted from the game
following a scrap which began when
the pair fell over each other into the
benches on the sidelines. A (I.-A-Re
fool V'as called and both were reGy had '11,moved Car.iey
personal fouls .rect;t,1 against lin.,
but Kelly was without any.
Reynolds Helps

Pete Reynolds, who substituted
for Kelly, became one of the leading
factors in the Hopkins victory. Reynolds was a bulwark on the defense
and helped considerably to direct
the passing on the offensive.
At this stage of the contest eighteen minutes remained to be play-.(1.
In less than three of these the
Hopkins forwards, Siverd and Siegel, took advantage of the excitement to tie the score at 19-19. The
score was tied again at 21-21, following which Siegel took the ball
out of Colvin's hands to count a
sleeper for Hopkins and put the
Jays in the lead for the first time at
23-21.

last Saturday at the K. of C. Pool,
and when the last event was finished
Hopkins had again emerged victorious, thus maintaining its clean
slate. The victim of the powerful
Blue Jay natators was the hitherto
unbeaten George Washington aggregation, conqueror of Lehigh,
Swarthmore, and Virginia, and possessor of one of the best swimming
teams in this section.
The final score was 34-25, with
the Black and Blue capturing the
final and deciding event, the 200yard relay. The crack Jay quartet,
composed of Lou Adler, Charlie
Jones, Woody White, and Frank
Levi, repeated its performance
against Manhattan and came through
in spectacular fashion to triumph
by five yards over the George
Washington swimmers.
Squads Evenly Matched

The two squads were amost evenly matched with both teams capturing three individual first-places. The
Hopkins natators jumped into the
lead in the opening event, Levi and
White taking first and second in the
50-yard dash against Capt. Max
Rote, who had never been beaten
before in intercollegiate competition.
Levi triumphed in the excellent time
of 25 seconds, which is just onefifth of a second short of the Hopkins,record.
The next Jay win came in the
440-yard dash, in which Lou Adler,
who broke the Jay record against
William and Mary last week, easily defeated his Capitol opponent.
The other Hopkins victory was
scored in the 150-yard backstroke,
with Johnny Magill triumphing over
Hain, District A. A. U. champion,
by a length of the body. Magill
won in the time of 2.01, which is
only two seconds away from the
Hopkins mark of 1.59.
Sadder Absent

George Washington mermen captured the dive, the 100-yard dash,
and the breaststroke. In the latter
race, Ghormley of the visitors
cracked the pool record as he led
home Hazlett of Hopkins in the
time of 2.42.3. However, the Blue
Jays were handicapped in this event
by the absence of Captain Eddie

ance with the widespread interest and ballyhoo attending
the Tilden-Vines tennis series,
THE NEWS-LETTER detailed
one of its reporters to witness
the match played in Baltimore
and to record his impressions.
They follow:

Professor Pitkin in his book Life
Begins At Forty tells us that we
do not begin living until we approach middle age.
This writer
does not question the general veracity of the statement, but after seeing the one-time king of the courts,
William Tatem Tilden, lose to the
youthful Henry Ellsworth Vines,
he is convinced that the professor
cannot be a tennis fan. For breaking Tilden's service continually
with hard forehand drives which
found the corners of the court,
Vines was not extended to win in
four sets, 6-8, 6-3, 7-5, 6-3.
Only for a few brief moments
did the audience catch glimpses of
the famous Tilden "cannon-ball",
which for the past 15 years has cut
a swath unequalled in tennis ranks.
Vines on the other hand was serving
with telling effectiveness, hitting
forehand shots that raked the corners, and above all volleying and
smashing with a severity which reminded many net enthusiasts of
Vinny Richards in his prime.
Tilden Center Of Interest

While the artistry of Vines drew
the applause of the fans time and
again, it was Tilden, as always, who
furnished the fireworks. One could
not help but think that the old master might still come through; the
crowd, although anticipating the result, still held a faint hope that the
Philadelphia wizard would, as in the
past, pull the match out of the fire.

KELLY AND CARNEY
EJECTED BY VOITH
Victory Enables Hopkins
Five To Finish In
Second Place
In a thrilling closing session in
which they overcame a first-period
14-9 lead, the Hopkins cagers defeated Loyola College Saturday
night, 33-28. This was the second
meeting of the two teams and the
Jays again proved their superiority
by repeating an early-season victory.
The triumph gives Hopkins a tie
for runner-up honors in the Maryland League. If Western Maryland
should defeat Mt. St. Mary's this
week, Hopkins will take second honors undisputed.
Loyola Begins Fast

The contest between the Jays and
Greyhounds packed all the thrills
that basketball spectators could ask
for. Loyola ran wild in the first
fifteen minutes of play to assume a
12-1 advantage, but Hopkins pulled
itself together and closed up the
count to 14-9 in favor of the Evergreen cagers at half time.
Only a few minutes after the
second half started, Don Kelly,
Hopkins guard, and Tom Carney,
Loyola, were evicted from the game
following a scrap which began when
the pair fell over each other into the
benches on the sidelines. A (I.-A-Re
fool V'as called and both were reGy had '11,moved Car.iey
personal fouls .rect;t,1 against lin.,
but Kelly was without any.
Reynolds Helps

Pete Reynolds, who substituted
for Kelly, became one of the leading
factors in the Hopkins victory. Reynolds was a bulwark on the defense
and helped considerably to direct
the passing on the offensive.
At this stage of the contest eighteen minutes remained to be play-.(1.
In less than three of these the
Hopkins forwards, Siverd and Siegel, took advantage of the excitement to tie the score at 19-19. The
score was tied again at 21-21, following which Siegel took the ball
out of Colvin's hands to count a
sleeper for Hopkins and put the
Jays in the lead for the first time at
23-21.

and when the last event was finished
Hopkins had again emerged victorious, thus maintaining its clean
slate. The victim of the powerful
Blue Jay natators was the hitherto
unbeaten George Washington aggregation, conqueror of Lehigh,
Swarthmore, and Virginia, and possessor of one of the best swimming
teams in this section.
The final score was 34-25, with
the Black and Blue capturing the
final and deciding event, the 200yard relay. The crack Jay quartet,
composed of Lou Adler, Charlie
Jones, Woody White, and Frank
Levi, repeated its performance
against Manhattan and came through
in spectacular fashion to triumph
by five yards over the George
Washington swimmers.
Squads Evenly Matched

The two squads were amost evenly matched with both teams capturing three individual first-places. The
Hopkins natators jumped into the
lead in the opening event, Levi and
White taking first and second in the
50-yard dash against Capt. Max
Rote, who had never been beaten
before in intercollegiate competition.
Levi triumphed in the excellent time
of 25 seconds, which is just onefifth of a second short of the Hopkins,record.
The next Jay win came in the
440-yard dash, in which Lou Adler,
who broke the Jay record against
William and Mary last week, easily defeated his Capitol opponent.
The other Hopkins victory was
scored in the 150-yard backstroke,
with Johnny Magill triumphing over
Hain, District A. A. U. champion,
by a length of the body. Magill
won in the time of 2.01, which is
only two seconds away from the
Hopkins mark of 1.59.
Sadder Absent

George Washington mermen captured the dive, the 100-yard dash,
and the breaststroke. In the latter
race, Ghormley of the visitors
cracked the pool record as he led
home Hazlett of Hopkins in the
time of 2.42.3. However, the Blue
Jays were handicapped in this event
by the absence of Captain Eddie

the Tilden-Vines tennis series,
THE NEWS-LETTER detailed
one of its reporters to witness
the match played in Baltimore
and to record his impressions.
They follow:

Professor Pitkin in his book Life
Begins At Forty tells us that we
do not begin living until we approach middle age.
This writer
does not question the general veracity of the statement, but after seeing the one-time king of the courts,
William Tatem Tilden, lose to the
youthful Henry Ellsworth Vines,
he is convinced that the professor
cannot be a tennis fan. For breaking Tilden's service continually
with hard forehand drives which
found the corners of the court,
Vines was not extended to win in
four sets, 6-8, 6-3, 7-5, 6-3.
Only for a few brief moments
did the audience catch glimpses of
the famous Tilden "cannon-ball",
which for the past 15 years has cut
a swath unequalled in tennis ranks.
Vines on the other hand was serving
with telling effectiveness, hitting
forehand shots that raked the corners, and above all volleying and
smashing with a severity which reminded many net enthusiasts of
Vinny Richards in his prime.
Tilden Center Of Interest

While the artistry of Vines drew
the applause of the fans time and
again, it was Tilden, as always, who
furnished the fireworks. One could
not help but think that the old master might still come through; the
crowd, although anticipating the result, still held a faint hope that the
Philadelphia wizard would, as in the
past, pull the match out of the fire.
